message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Emergent social conventions and collective bias in LLM populations
Paper Abstract: Social conventions are the backbone of social coordination, shaping how individuals form a group. As growing populations of artificial intelligence (AI) agents communicate through natural language, a fundamental question is whether they can bootstrap the foundations of a society. Here, we present experimental results that demonstrate the spontaneous emergence of universally adopted social conventions in decentralized populations of large language model (LLM) agents. We then show how strong collective biases can emerge during this process, even when agents exhibit no bias individually. Last, we examine how committed minority groups of adversarial LLM agents can drive social change by imposing alternative social conventions on the larger population. Our results show that AI systems can autonomously develop social conventions without explicit programming and have implications for designing AI systems that align, and remain aligned, with human values and societal goals.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Natural Language Processing

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

### Key Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

### Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

### Modern Advances

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017 and the concept of large language models (LLM) emerged in late 2010s, with LLM being a language model trained with self-supervised learning on vast amounts of text.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

### Modern Advances

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017 and the concept of large language models (LLM) emerged in late 2010s, with LLM being a language model trained with self-supervised learning on vast amounts of text.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

## Definition
A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)These can be simulated entities or real software agents or robots.

## Key Capabilities
Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)Intelligence may include methodic, functional, procedural approaches, algorithmic search or reinforcement learning.

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, typically referring to software agents, though the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Key characteristics include autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and self-aware) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

Links: [{"title":"Wikipedia:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Large_language_models"},{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Category:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models"},{"title":"List of large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models/Archive_1"},{"title":"Language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Writing articles with large language models/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Writing_articles_with_large_language_models/Archive_1"},{"title":"1.58-bit large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1.58-bit_large_language_model"},{"title":"Llama (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLaMA"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of large language models:

## What are Large Language Models?

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Key Characteristics

These models consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.

## Capabilities and Importance

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. These LLMs are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs).

## Limitations

These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

I've completed the web search for "Social conventions." Here's what I found:

## Overview

In sociology, a social rule refers to any social convention commonly adhered to in a society.(no content)These rules are not written in law or otherwise formalized.

## Key Characteristics

A convention influences a set of agreed, stipulated, or generally accepted standards, social norms, or other criteria, often taking the form of a custom.(no content)Often the word refers to unwritten customs shared throughout a community. For example, it is conventional in many societies that strangers being introduced shake hands.

## Socially Constructed Nature

These rules are socially constructed, that these rules act upon every member of a society, but at the same time, are re-produced by the individuals. Additionally, these are specific to the social context, a context that varies through time and place. That means a social rule changes over time within the same society.

## Examples

Social conventions include various norms across different domains, such as tipping in the US to waitresses and waiters, as well as numerous gender-specific conventions regarding dress, behavior, and roles in society.

The search results show that social conventions are fundamental to how societies organize behavior and expectations, though they remain flexible and subject to change across time and cultures.

Links: [{"title":"List of cognitive biases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_biases"},{"title":"Collective behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_behavior"},{"title":"Cognitive bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_bias"},{"title":"Shared information bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shared_information_bias"},{"title":"Group attribution error - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_attribution_error"},{"title":"In-group favoritism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In-group_favoritism"},{"title":"Authority bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authority_bias"},{"title":"Crowd psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crowd_psychology"},{"title":"Social influence bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence_bias"},{"title":"Collective action problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_action_problem"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about collective behavior bias:

## Understanding Collective Behavior Bias

The search results reveal several interconnected concepts related to collective behavior bias:

### Cognitive Biases and Collective Behavior

Cognitive biases are interlinked with collective illusions, a phenomenon where a group of people mistakenly believe that their views and preferences are shared by the majority, when in reality, they are not.

### Types of Collective Biases

Several specific biases operate at the group level:

**Shared Information Bias:** This is the tendency for group members to spend more time andenergy discussing information that all members are already familiar with (i.e., shared information), and less time and energy discussing information that only some members are aware of (i.e., unshared information).

**Group Attribution Error:** The group attribution error refers to people's tendency to believe either the characteristics of an individual group member are reflective of the group as a whole, or a group's decision outcome must reflect the preferences of individual group members, even when external information is available suggesting otherwise.

**In-group Favoritism:** In-group favoritism, sometimes known as in-group–out-group bias, in-group bias, intergroup bias, or in-group preference, is a pattern of favoring members of one's in-group over out-group members.

**Authority Bias:** Authority bias is considered one of the social cognitive biases or collective cognitive biases.

### How Collective Behavior Works

Collective behavior constitutes social processes and events which do not reflect existing social structure (laws, conventions, and institutions), but which emerge in a "spontaneous" way, and is always driven by group dynamics, encouraging people to engage in acts they might consider unthinkable under typical social circumstances.

These collective biases significantly impact group decision-making and social dynamics across various contexts.

I've completed a web search for "Artificial intelligence agents." Here's a comprehensive overview of what I found:

## Definition and Core Concepts

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.(no content)A specialized subset of intelligent agents, agentic AI (also known as an AI agent or simply agent), expands this concept by proactively pursuing goals, making decisions, and taking actions over extended periods.

## Range of Complexity

Intelligent agents can range from simple to highly complex. A basic thermostat or control system is considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria—such as a firm, a state, or a biome.

## Types of Agents

**Autonomous Agents:** An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.

**Embodied Agents:** In artificial intelligence, an embodied agent, also sometimes referred to as an interface agent, is an intelligent agent that interacts with the environment through a physical body within that environment.

## Real-World Examples

ChatGPT and the Roomba vacuum are examples of goal-based agents.

## Multi-Agent Systems

In 1975 distributed artificial intelligence emerged as a subfield of artificial intelligence that dealt with interactions of intelligent agents. Distributed artificial intelligence systems were conceived as a group of intelligent entities, called agents, that interacted by cooperation, by coexistence or by competition.

The search results provide a wealth of information on AI agents, from foundational definitions to modern implementations and emerging technologies in the field.

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of "Emergent social conventions and collective bias in LLM populations". Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper presents novel experimental results on the emergence of social conventions in LLM populations and demonstrates previously unknown properties of collective bias in AI systems.

**Extracted Triples (6 total):**

1. **Large language model** (artifact, uses) - Core AI systems being studied
2. **Convention (norm)** (concept, proposes) - Spontaneous emergence demonstrated as novel finding
3. **Intelligent agent** (concept, uses) - Fundamental entities in the framework
4. **Collective behavior** (concept, proposes) - New understanding of how collective biases emerge
5. **Multi-agent system** (concept, uses) - Decentralized population framework
6. **Natural language processing** (concept, uses) - Communication mechanism between agents

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED - All 6 triples validated successfully with correct Wikipedia URLs and proper entity classifications.

Sources:
- [Large language model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model)
- [Convention (norm)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_(norm))
- [Intelligent agent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent)
- [Collective behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_behavior)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Natural language processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing)
